content.description: An experiment was performed to determine the mode of inheritance of two mouse genes, one for fur color and one for fur length. It is known that black fur (<math alttext="uppercase B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) is dominant over white fur (<math alttext="lowercase b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) and that long fur (<math alttext="uppercase L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) is dominant over short fur (<math alttext="lowercase l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>). To determine how the genes are inherited, a cross was performed between two true-breeding mice, one with long black fur and one with short white fur.
